Eric John Hewitt FRS (27 February 1919–01 January 2002) was a British plant physiologist. He is commonly known for compiling and publishing the Long Ashton Nutrient Solution. 
Hewitt was educated at Whitgift School, graduated with a first-class BSc in botany and chemistry from King's College London, and completed his PhD at the University of Bristol in 1948. Hewitt's laboratory at Long Ashton Research Station openend in 1956. He was a Reader in Plant Physiology at the University of Bristol from 1967 to 1984.
He was made a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1982.

response: Long Ashton is also commonly known for the Long Ashton Nutrient Solution (LANS). It was derived from nutrient solutions used at Long Ashton to grow fruit trees and first published in 1952 in a standard work on plant nutrition by Eric John Hewitt.Hewitt E. J. (1952). Sand and Water Culture Methods Used in the Study of Plant Nutrition. Farnham Royal, England: Commonwealth Agricultural Bureaux, pp. 241. Technical Communication No. 22 of the Commonwealth Bureau of Horticulture and Plantation Crops. The LANS concentrations for each essential element and sodium in a full solution of the nitrate-type are shown below. In particular, the composition and concentration of the micronutrients (B, Mn, Zn, Cu, and Mo) is still commonly used in plant science today (cf. Table (1)). The LANS micronutrients can be combined with the macronutrients of the Hoagland solution. According to Hewitt iron is available as ferric citrate or it may be prepared as ferric EDTA complex.Hewitt E. J. (1966). Sand and Water Culture Methods Used in the Study of Plant Nutrition.
